references: The accuracy results are shown in Table 1. Within the current state-of-the-art FL algorithms (upper portion of Table 1), MOON achieves the best accuracy. This is expected, as MOON is the most intricate of the FL methods, requiring the usage of three individual models for its contrastive learning technique. However, when we compare with standard regularization techniques (Mixup, StochDepth and GradAug in the lower portion of Table 1), we see that these perform similarly or substantially better. GradAug particularly stands out, achieving an accuracy âˆ¼similar-to\sim2% higher than MOON and âˆ¼similar-to\sim4% higher than FedAvg and FedProx. StochDepth also achieves similar accuracy to MOON. Furthermore, these regularization methods bring the same or better performance than MOON, with less memory and/or compute requirements. We find that regularization methods appear to have an advantage in this situation; however, we wish to further investigate why this could be the case. Next, we present our in-depth analysis based on second-order information in Section 3.4.

In Table 1, we include the results of the Hessian analysis. First, we find that FedAvg has the highest Î»mâ€‹aâ€‹xsubscriptğœ†ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥\lambda_{max}Â and HTsubscriptğ»ğ‘‡H_{T}. FedProx and MOON each result in lower values, indicating some degree of improved generalization. However, interestingly, we find that regularization methods are most effective at reducing the Î»mâ€‹aâ€‹xsubscriptğœ†ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥\lambda_{max}Â and HTsubscriptğ»ğ‘‡H_{T}, with GradAug having by far the lowest in both values. We visualize the effect of this reduction in Î»mâ€‹aâ€‹xsubscriptğœ†ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥\lambda_{max}Â and HTsubscriptğ»ğ‘‡H_{T}Â in Fig. 1, where it can be seen that GradAug is able to smooth out the loss landscape considerably in comparison to FedAvg.

Here, âŠ™direct-product\odot is the dot product, ğ‡ksubscriptğ‡ğ‘˜\mathbf{H}_{k} and ğ‡jsubscriptğ‡ğ‘—\mathbf{H}_{j} are the Hessian matrices of clients kğ‘˜k and jğ‘—j, and âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥F\left\|\cdot\right\|_{F} is the Frobenius norm. HNk,jsuperscriptsubscriptğ»ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—H_{N}^{k,j} and HDk,jsuperscriptsubscriptğ»ğ·ğ‘˜ğ‘—H_{D}^{k,j} are averaged across all pairs of clients and reported as simply HNsubscriptğ»ğ‘H_{N}Â and HDsubscriptğ»ğ·H_{D}Â in Table 1. For these Hessian matching criteria, a lower HNsubscriptğ»ğ‘H_{N}Â (less difference) and a higher HDsubscriptğ»ğ·H_{D}Â (essentially the cosine similarity) are desired.

As seen on the right side of Table 1, HDsubscriptğ»ğ·H_{D}Â is fairly consistent across all methods. In terms of Î»mâ€‹aâ€‹xsubscriptğœ†ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥\lambda_{max}, HTsubscriptğ»ğ‘‡H_{T}, and HDsubscriptğ»ğ·H_{D}, most methods seem to correlate decently well between these values and performance. However, there are a few cases which require more information. First, Mixup has a similar HTsubscriptğ»ğ‘‡H_{T}Â value as MOON, but lower accuracy. HNsubscriptğ»ğ‘H_{N}Â provides another detail; the Hessian norms of Mixup are not nearly as similar across clients as those of MOON. Between MOON and StochDepth, we see that MOON has both a higher Î»mâ€‹aâ€‹xsubscriptğœ†ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥\lambda_{max}Â and HTsubscriptğ»ğ‘‡H_{T}, but StochDepth has a higher HNsubscriptğ»ğ‘H_{N}. In the end, MOON and StochDepth result in similar performance, with perhaps a slight edge towards the latter.

The default hyperparameter setting used throughout the paper is Ï‰S=0.25subscriptğœ”ğ‘†0.25\omega_{S}=0.25 and Î¼=0.45ğœ‡0.45\mu=0.45. The performance of FedAlignÂ with various hyperparameters on the CIFAR-100 basic setting (described in Section 3.2 of the main paper) is shown in Table 10. We vary Î¼ğœ‡\mu and Ï‰Ssubscriptğœ”ğ‘†\omega_{S} independently, meaning Ï‰S=0.25subscriptğœ”ğ‘†0.25\omega_{S}=0.25 for the Î¼ğœ‡\mu ablations, and Î¼=0.45ğœ‡0.45\mu=0.45 when varying Ï‰Ssubscriptğœ”ğ‘†\omega_{S}.
Table 10 shows that FedAlignÂ is more sensitive to Ï‰ssubscriptğœ”ğ‘ \omega_{s} than Î¼ğœ‡\mu; nonetheless, we found Ï‰=0.25ğœ”0.25\omega=0.25 to be a versatile choice in practice.
Furthermore, hyperparameters only need to be decided once, as they transfer well across a variety of other datasets and FL settings as shown in Section 4.1 of the main paper.

Data Heterogeneity.
Federated systems can be deployed with many different setups and diverse environments. We conduct further analysis across a variety of FL settings to ensure the generality of our findings. First, we examine the effect of varying the degree of heterogeneity in the client data distributions. The results are shown in Table 2. We report the mean accuracy Â±plus-or-minus\pm the standard deviation across three runs. All other settings are maintained from Section 3.2; only the data distribution Dâ€‹iâ€‹râ€‹(Î±)ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ›¼Dir(\alpha) is varied. A lower Î±ğ›¼\alpha value indicates a more heterogeneous distribution.

As the degree of data heterogeneity decreases, the effect of client drift should become less significant. Therefore, we expect that the accuracy for each method will increase, with peak performance in the homogeneous setting. All regularization methods, as well as FedAvg, perform as expected, and find consistent improvement across the degrees of data distribution. However, we see that the accuracy improvement of FedProx and MOON slows as the data approaches homogeneity, with accuracy in the purely homogeneous setting (â€œhomogâ€ in Table 2) remaining quite low. In their attempt to mitigate client drift and keep local updates close to the global model, it appears that they also hinder their ability to fully learn on minorly heterogeneous or even homogeneous data. This is not ideal for deployable FL systems, as the degree of heterogeneity is not known ahead of time. Moreover, even in the most heterogeneous cases, the structural regularization methods perform better than the standard FL algorithms. For instance, StochDepth achieves a âˆ¼similar-to\sim1.7% improvement over MOON at Î±ğ›¼\alpha = 0.10.10.1, while also having improvement in more homogeneous situations.
In all settings, GradAug performs the best.

Number of Local Training Epochs.
The main purpose for adequately handling data heterogeneity is to allow for more productive training on the client each round, therefore reducing the time to convergence and required communication cost. Therefore, to examine the training productivity of each method, we examine their accuracy with various allotted local training epochs per round (Eğ¸E) in Table 3.

Ideally methods should continue to improve in accuracy with more allotted local training epochs. In Table 3, we see that all methods steadily improve from 10 epochs per round to 20. However, from 20 to 30, the trends vary considerably. As a baseline, FedAvg slightly improves by âˆ¼similar-to\sim0.3%. Surprisingly, FedProx and MOON stay relatively stagnant from 20 to 30 epochs. Meanwhile, the standard (particularly structural) regularization methods continue to increase in accuracy. Therefore, these methods illustrate the ability to maintain productive training, even across a wide range of allotted local epochs.

Number of Clients.
In real-world FL settings, the number of participating clients can vary widely. Moreover, only a portion of clients are potentially sampled per round, whether for connectivity reasons or other capacity restrictions of the central system. Therefore, it is crucial that an FL method can converge under such conditions. We study the affect of client number and client sampling in Table 4. C=64Ã—0.25ğ¶640.25C=64\times 0.25 indicates that there are 64 total clients in the system, but only a fraction (0.25) are sampled each round. The rest of the presented results in Table 4 sample all Kğ¾K clients each round. C=64Ã—0.25ğ¶640.25C=64\times 0.25 (100) is run for 100 rounds, and all other settings for the default 25 rounds.

references:
Overall, we find that GradAug is particularly effective in the FL setting, having the highest accuracy in all tested scenarios along with the lowest Î»mâ€‹aâ€‹xsubscriptğœ†ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥\lambda_{max}, HTsubscriptğ»ğ‘‡H_{T}, and HNsubscriptğ»ğ‘H_{N}.
However, while this method is quite memory efficient in comparison to many FL methods (only requires a single stored model during training), it does incur a substantial increase in training time and local computation over the FedAvg baseline. This is because GradAug requires multiple forward passes through slimmed sub-networks for the distillation loss. It is possible to reduce the computation burden to some extent by using a smaller number of sub-networks during the knowledge distillation process, as seen in Table 5. Here, the Î¼ğœ‡\mu in GradAug is adjusted to 2.0, 1.5, and 1.25 for nğ‘›n = 1, 3, and 4, respectively. Nonetheless, a considerable gap still remains between GradAug and vanilla FedAvg in local compute requirements and subsequent wall-clock time.
Therefore, the question is, can we devise a method which provides similar effect and performance as GradAug in FL, but with substantially less computational overhead? This is particularly important in the FL setting, where clients are typically deployed devices with minimal memory and computational resources.

As seen in Table 5, FedAlignÂ achieves state-of-the-art accuracy in a resource-efficient manner.
With just a 1.02x difference in FLOPs, FedAlignÂ realizes a significant âˆ¼similar-to\sim4.0% accuracy improvement over the FedAvg baseline.
For the FL algorithms FedProx and MOON, they not only have much lower accuracy than FedAlign, but also require substantially more compute and/or memory. Particularly, FedAlignÂ achieves a âˆ¼similar-to\sim1.9% accuracy improvement over MOON, while reducing the local compute overhead by over 65% and the memory requirements by over 70%. Furthermore, FedAlignÂ realizes a critical âˆ¼similar-to\sim47% and âˆ¼similar-to\sim33% reduction in compute needs compared to GradAug with (n=2ğ‘›2n=2) and (n=1ğ‘›1n=1), without sacrificing accuracy.

We further verify the effectiveness of our method across various settings and datasets. In Table 6, we examine the performance of FedAlignÂ with the same ablations as in Section 3.5, where FedAlignÂ exhibits strong performance in many settings. We also investigate FedAlignÂ and all other methods across two additional datasets: CIFAR-10 and ImageNet-200. For ImageNet-200, we randomly sample 200 classes from the classic ImageNet-1k [22] dataset. We employ ResNet56 and ResNet18 [5] as our models on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet-200, respectively. For FedAlign, Ï‰S=0.25subscriptğœ”ğ‘†0.25\omega_{S}=0.25 and Î¼=0.45ğœ‡0.45\mu=0.45 in all results.
Hyperparameters for all other methods are those described in Section 3.2 (with Î¼=2.0ğœ‡2.0\mu=2.0 for GradAug (n=1ğ‘›1n=1) as in Table 5). For additional analyses, please refer to the supplementary material.

references: For CIFAR-10, we ran a 16 client synchronous and 64 client case with sampling in Table 7. We note similar trends to CIFAR-100; regularization methods perform well, particularly in the more realistic client sampling case. On ImageNet-200, we also ran synchronous and sampling settings. Here, both GradAug and FedAlignÂ maintain higher performance than other methods. FedAlignÂ provides competitive accuracy with GradAug (n=1ğ‘›1n=1) and even (n=2ğ‘›2n=2) in the sampling case, while reducing computational needs by a significant margin. Interestingly, StochDepth does not perform as well in the ImageNet-200 cases. As mentioned in the original paper [6], Stochastic Depth performs better with deeper networks. However, with ResNet18, the overall depth of the network is reduced compared to that in the CIFAR cases. Therefore, as most deployable networks favor width over depth, regularizing with respect to the width of a network is more applicable to the FL setting. This highlights an additional benefit of FedAlign, which operates using width reduction in the final block and maintains relatively high accuracy despite low resource needs.

Communication cost is another critical factor in FL systems, as participating client devices are often on slow or congested networks [17].
Therefore, total efficiency in FL systems includes both the ability to reduce the local computational burden, as well as the communication overhead. We evaluate all methods with such measures in Table 8. We maintain the CIFAR-100 setting described in Section 3.2 of the main paper, except that we do not limit the number of rounds, but rather allow all methods to reach a common accuracy of 60%. This allows us to analyze the total costs of each method consistently. FedAlignÂ proves to be the most efficient in all respects, achieving the target accuracy in less number of rounds, less communication cost, and less local computation.

In Table 9, we show the second-order analysis results for FedAlignÂ along with the other methods. The Liptzshitz-focused distillation loss of FedAlignÂ  effectively reduces the Lipshitz constant Î»mâ€‹aâ€‹xsubscriptğœ†ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥\lambda_{max}Â considerably as intended (FedAlignÂ results in the lowest Î»mâ€‹aâ€‹xsubscriptğœ†ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥\lambda_{max}Â across all methods), and therefore helps provide stronger generalization and performance.
However, one limitation to FedAlignÂ is that it does not directly translate to a strong reduction in HNsubscriptğ»ğ‘H_{N}.
Therefore, a promising direction for future work could extend FedAlignÂ to also consider this aspect.
